column1: Note: From 1852-1967 the Unfertilized and two FYM treatments did not receive any fertilizer N.
In 1968 the main plots were divided to test four rates of N (0, 48, 96 and 144 kg N ha-1, shown as N0, N1, N2 and N3 respectively). Since 1974 the rates
applied to the four subplots each year have rotated, in the order N3 > N2 > N1 > N0. Thus, since 1968, data from the subplot receiving N0 in any one year has
been used for the Unfertilized, FYM and FYM 1852-1871 treatments, and data from the subplot receiving N1 has been used for the PKMg+N1 treatment.
For the NPKMg and FYM+N treatments, means of the greatest yield achieved with N each year are shown; these received a maximum of 144 kgN ha-1.
In some years, the greatest yield for the FYM+N treatment came from the N0 subplot; the greatest yield from the NPKMg treatment was always given by the
N2 or N3 subplot.

column3: Fallowing and cultivation of the whole experiment was used to control weeds.
The experiment was bare fallowed in 1912, 1933, 1943 and 1967.
Herbicides were introduced in 1945; previously weeds were controlled by hand hoeing.
Lime (calcium carbonate, often referred to as chalk) has been applied since
1955 to maintain soil pH at a level which does not limit yield.
Modern short-strawed, high-yielding cultivars have been grown since 1970.
Spring and summer fungicides applied as necessary since 1978.
